comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -32,6 +32,10 @@ Note that, the oqs-nginx-{LIBOQS_VERSION}.tgz package contains all required conf
 
 #### Activation
 
-Execute `/opt/nginx/sbin/nginx -c /opt/nginx/interop.conf` to start the test server.
+Execute `OPENSSL_CONF=/opt/openssl/.openssl/ssl/openssl.cnf /opt/nginx/sbin/nginx -c /opt/nginx/interop.conf` to start the test server.
comment.body: This doesn't look like an "under-the-hood" change invisible to users: Doesn't this warrant updating at least USAGE.md for `nginx`? Why is this apparently user-API changing version update necessary?

pull_request.title: Updates docker file to create test server package
pull_request.body:
The update uses..
- liboqs 0.9.0
- latest oqs-provider (main)
- latest nginx 1.25.2

Also updates the nginx docker demo to v1.25.2.
Note that with [nginx 1.25.2](http://nginx.org/en/CHANGES), the location of the openssl config file needs to be passed as an env variable. This is reflected in the Dockerfile of the nginx demo.

The updated package is already deployed at test.openquantumsafe.org.
A test run with `testrun.sh` passes.
I'll update the server again to a tagged oqs-provider release once available.

repo.name: oqs-demos
repo.description: Instructions for enabling the use of quantum-safe cryptography in assorted software using the OQS suite

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -126,6 +126,5 @@ STOPSIGNAL SIGTERM
 # Enable a normal user to create new server keys off set CA
 RUN addgroup -g 1000 -S oqs && adduser --uid 1000 -S oqs -G oqs && chown -R oqs.oqs ${INSTALLDIR}
 USER oqs
-
+ENV OPENSSL_CONF ${OSSLDIR}/ssl/openssl.cnf
comment.body: This bypasses all `nginx` config logic. Why is this necessary? Shouldn't this be documented somewhere?

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -18,10 +18,10 @@ ARG SIG_ALG="dilithium3"
 ARG DEFAULT_GROUPS=x25519:x448:kyber512:p256_kyber512:kyber768:p384_kyber768:kyber1024:p521_kyber1024
 
 # define the nginx version to include
-ARG NGINX_VERSION=1.23.3
+ARG NGINX_VERSION=1.25.2
 
 # Define the degree of parallelism when building the image; leave the number away only if you know what you are doing
-ARG MAKE_DEFINES="-j 18"
+ARG MAKE_DEFINES="-j"
comment.body: This change will make any "few cores" machine running this squeak, possibly crash (have seen this before). I appreciate that "modern laptops" couldn't care less but we don't prescribe this for building the demos. Also, some CI systems (notably CCI) has problems with unlimited "-j". The 18 was what CCI could handle without failures. Unless you can point to a document stating improved CCI capabilities, please revert.
